abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Mineral Sector
            Management Project for Guinea was satisfactory. The project
            achieved some of its objectives, its impact on institutional
            development was significant, sustainability is unlikely, and
            the performance of both the Bank and Borrower was
            satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, the benefit of the project could have been
            enhanced by more careful project preparation, particularly
            in coordination with other donors, better project
            definition, and stronger conditionality. Second, it would
            have been more beneficial and effective if the consultants
            had prepared their final reports in the field, in
            consultation with their Guinean counterparts, instead of
            preparing them in their home country. Third, from the
            beginning, Guinean working level staff should have been
            consulted in contract negotiation to avoid interminable
            discussions with the consultant after contract signature.
            Fourth, the consulting firm selected for project
            coordination must manage to maintain expert staffing for as
            long as possible to facilitate continuation of the work,
            especially in the field of training higher level Guinean
            staff. Finally, Guinean staff should be more fully
            integrated in the preparation of project reports.

abstracts.cdata!:
The project would finance technical
            assistance to help the Government of Guinea (GOG) manage its
            mining shareholdings, undertake geological work and
            exploration promotion, improve the mining sector's
            regulatory framework, and strengthen institutional
            efficiency through administrative reform. Technical
            assistance would be provided for: (a) shareholding
            management; (b) exploration promotion; (c) regulatory
            control; and (d) reorginazation of the General Directorate
            of Mines and Geology (DGMG).
